intro: Lupinus maissurianii, commonly known as the Caucasian lupine, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of blue to violet pea-like flowers. The plant has palmately compound leaves with several leaflets, and its root system includes nitrogen-fixing nodules, which contribute to soil fertility. Lupinus maissurianii is adapted to rocky and well-drained soils, often growing in alpine or subalpine environments.
